Award.AbstractNarration:
This project sets up a new REU site at Carnegie-Mellon University focused on multi-faceted aspects of software engineering. The program will be recruiting a diverse set of students based on stop-past-the-post strategy successfully employed previously by other sites. The site will focus on recruiting women students and students from undergraduate-only institutions with limited research exposure. The students will not only be acquiring research skills through the training program, but also gain exposure to a broader research landscape through interactions and seminars. The students will be exposed to faculty life and research career paths.

Skills in software engineering have always been core to computer science, programming and software development. The project will offer research opportunity in secure languages, requirement engineering, program repair, variational data structures and API usability. The projects emphasize separate modules on training, exposure and graduate life mentoring. The project will build on the experience of many of the faculty mentors who have worked with undergraduate students in their individual research. The students will be encouraged to disseminate their research findings by publishing in quality venues and giving presentations.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this REU Site program was to increase undergraduate student interest and involvement in world-class interdisciplinary software engineering research. Software Engineering research addresses how to efficiently the build high quality, secure, and innovative software systems, like those that govern nearly all aspects of modern life. It therefore tackles problems of critical national, global, and economic importance. It is also a deeply interdisciplinary field, touching on human computer interaction, security, systems, programming languages, statistics, and various other subfields both within and beyond computer science.

One of our main ambitions has been to broaden the pipeline of undergraduate students interested in pursuing research careers. We specifically focused on recruiting students who might not otherwise have research opportunities at their undergraduate institutions, and on reaching members of groups traditionally underrepresented in computer science, including women. We provided our students with a miniature version of graduate school, over the course of a summer. We taught them how to define a research project, learn about and apply a research method, validate their results, present their work to their peers, and write a summative paper. We also provided social and professional development outlets, including a summer series on subjects like research skills, access to thesis proposals and defenses, and participation in research seminars and reading groups.

Our site has been very successful at our overall goal of attracting students to research careers. More than 80% of the students funded by this award are now doing research full-time, or are planning to apply to graduate school when they graduate. Graduated students are conducting research at major government, academic, and corporate laboratories (e.g., IBM TJ Watson Research, Microsoft Research, Oak Ridge National Laboratory) or are attending top PhD programs, including (but not limited to) Northwestern, University of Illinois - Urbana Champaign, Rutgers, and Carnegie Mellon University. This is especially remarkable given the competitive economic landscape for well-trained software engineers.

We also attracted a highly diverse group of summer students. More than half of the students who have participated in our program identify as women, and more than 20% identify as members of other underrepresented groups in computing. Approximately 2/3 of our students attend undergraduate-focused liberal arts or regional state colleges, lacking access to traditional research opportunities at their home institutions. The Site award formed the cornerstone of our department's summer research program, which includes more students than are directly funded by this award (65 overall). The students in the program overall have similar demographics to those funded directly by this award. 

The funded research also contributed substantially to advancing the state-of-the-art in interdisciplinary software engineering research. This research is on diverse subjects, from studying how to test for bugs in robotic and autonomy systems, to how to construct programming languages that make it easier to write correct programs from scratch and avoid certain kinds of important programming mistakes, to testing and securing devices in the Internet of Things. Overall, our students contributed to more than 25 peer-reviewed, publish papers or conference presentations, and received awards at multiple student research competitions at top international research conferences.
